items.synopsis: In 1994, a looter code-named The Falcon dug up an ancient treasure that decades later would end up in an Australian gallery. Now, it's being given back.

image.altText: Canada's Trudeau self-isolates as wife is tested for coronavirus

items.synopsis: Today's latest news, as it happens.

title.children: Canadian PM separates from wife, shooter scare sends US Senate offices into lockdown — catch up with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ABC's Brad Ryan joins us from Washington with more: Jade: Police in Washington DC have been preparing for Donald Trump’s appearance in a local court tomorrow, and they’ve already had to deal with a security scare overnight. Local police said a 911 caller reported an active shooter in the Capitol district about 2:30pm local time (4:30am AEST). Officers were on the scene “within seconds”, searching the Senate office buildings and telling political staffers inside to shelter in place. But the local police chief has just held a press conference, where he said they found no signs of a shooting or a shooter. He said local police and partner agencies such as the Secret Service were “prepared for whatever might happen tomorrow”. Mr Trump is scheduled to appear in court at 4pm local time (6am AEST), but it’s not known if he will show up in person or dial in virtually. The courthouse is about a 10-minute walk from the Capitol building, which was stormed by Trump supporters on January 6, 2021.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US police are 'prepared for whatever might happen' ahead of Donald Trump's court appearance

children.content: The ABC's
Brad Ryan
joins us from Washington with more:
Jade:
Police in Washington DC have been preparing for Donald Trump’s appearance in a local court tomorrow, and they’ve already had to deal with a security scare overnight.
Local police said a 911 caller reported an active shooter in the Capitol district about 2:30pm local time (4:30am AEST).
Officers were on the scene “within seconds”, searching the Senate office buildings and telling political staffers inside to shelter in place.
But the local police chief has just held a press conference, where he said they found no signs of a shooting or a shooter.
He said local police and partner agencies such as the Secret Service were “prepared for whatever might happen tomorrow”.
Mr Trump is scheduled to appear in court at 4pm local time (6am AEST), but it’s not known if he will show up in person or dial in virtually.
The courthouse is about a 10-minute walk from the Capitol building, which was stormed by Trump supporters on January 6, 2021.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Two of Lizzo's former dancers — who are suing the US singer for misconduct — say others are scared to speak out. Arianna Davis and Crystal Williams have told the CBS network that they filed the claim in the hope of preventing colleagues from suffering. "Nobody speaks up because they're so scared for their jobs," Ms Davis said. "I was terrified for my job," she added. Their legal action includes accusations of sexual, religious and racial harassment, discrimination, assault and false imprisonment. Lizzo and others on her team who are named in the lawsuit are yet to respond to the allegations.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Lizzo's former dancer discusses lawsuit against singer, says she was 'terrified' for her job

featuredLink.title: Lizzo's former dancers file lawsuit against singer

children.content: Two of Lizzo's former dancers — who are suing the US singer for misconduct — say others are scared to speak out.
Arianna Davis and Crystal Williams have told the CBS network that they filed the claim in the hope of preventing colleagues from suffering.
"Nobody speaks up because they're so scared for their jobs," Ms Davis said.
"I was terrified for my job," she added.
Their legal action includes accusations of sexual, religious and racial harassment, discrimination, assault and false imprisonment.
Lizzo and others on her team who are named in the lawsuit are yet to respond to the allegations.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: That's according to US police, who were responding to earlier reports of an active shooter in the nation's Capitol, which led to Senate offices being locked down. "A call came in for an active shooter. It appears to be a bad call. No injuries and no shooter were located," Washington Metropolitan Police Department spokesman Hugh Carew said. One Senate staffer said that while the Capitol building itself was not on the highest level of lockdown, police advised all workers there to remain in their offices. There was a heavy police presence outside the buildings, with some staffers standing outside and tourists gathered around the perimeters of the Capitol complex.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: No shooter, no injuries reported at US Capitol after 'bad call'

children.content: That's according to US police, who were responding to
earlier reports of an active shooter in the nation's Capitol, which led to Senate offices being locked down.
"A call came in for an active shooter. It appears to be a bad call. No injuries and no shooter were located," Washington Metropolitan Police Department spokesman Hugh Carew said.

props.alt: U.S. Senate staff members evacuate under police supervision after an unconfirmed report of an active shooter

children.content: (Reuters)
One Senate staffer said that while the Capitol building itself was not on the highest level of lockdown, police advised all workers there to remain in their offices.
There was a heavy police presence outside the buildings, with some staffers standing outside and tourists gathered around the perimeters of the Capitol complex.
